posts.name: Tomer
posts.cooked: dose anybods has an idea for an electronic project to pass the time for the new teamates and for them to gain experience?

posts.name: Ryan Radtke
posts.cooked: I learned by making a test bench and rewire our outreach bot

posts.name: segev
posts.cooked: The way I learned electronics the best is I practiced soldering and fixing old (broken) robots. But probably the best and most team working project you can do is to rewire an old robot

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: There are thousands of kits on the Internet. Check out the CD thread Electrical Activities For soldering practice my team has these C6881 - 4 in 1 Learn to Solder - Package B| The Electronic Goldmine

link_counts.title: C6881 - 4 in 1 Learn to Solder - Package B| The Electronic Goldmine

posts.name: Alya Kurt
posts.cooked: For our team, we used Fritzing with our new members. It helped them a lot with understanding which part connects to what. Here are some Fritzing parts that come in handy. https://github.com/AronRubin/FRCFritzingParts , https://github.com/belaw888/ FRC -Fritzing-Parts , and https://github.com/team401/ FRC -Fritzing-Parts

link_counts.title: GitHub - AronRubin/FRCFritzingParts: Additional Parts I authored for Fritzing
GitHub - team401/FRC-Fritzing-Parts: Custom FRC Components for Fritzing

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
The XRP is a great and extensible platform.

You don’t need to know much about electronics for FIRST .  95% of “electronics” is just running power wires to the right place.  Stripping wires, soldering and crimping are important skills.

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: We have a pit training exercise where we bring in a past robot and mess up the electrical board. After that, we timed members and saw how long it took them to notice and fix all the issues.

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked: I like the TKO FRC Electronics simulator. Its good to learn the basics in wiring can as well as motor controllers.
